original: Milindapañha
analyzed: milindapañha
translated: The Questions of King Milinda

original: Meṇḍakapañha
analyzed: meṇḍakapañha
translated: The Questions of Menander

original: Santhavavagga
analyzed: santhava vagga
translated: The Chapter about the Forest

original: 8. Brāhmaṇarājavādapañha
translated: The Questions of the Brahmins and the King

original: “Bhante nāgasena, bhāsitampetaṁ tathāgatena ‘ahamasmi, bhikkhave, brāhmaṇo yācayogo’ti.
analyzed: bhante nāgasena tathāgatena aham asmi bhikkhave brāhmaṇaḥ
translated: “Venerable Nāgasena, this was said by the Lord Buddha: ‘I am a brahmin, monks, a beggar.’

original: Puna ca bhaṇitaṁ—
analyzed: punar ca bhaṇita
translated: And again it is said:

original: ‘rājāhamasmi selā’ti.
analyzed: rājā aham asmi selāti
translated: ‘I am King of the Sela people.’

original: Yadi, bhante nāgasena, bhagavatā bhaṇitaṁ—
analyzed: yadi bhante nāgasena bhagavatā bhaṇita
translated: If the first statement was made by the Buddha,

original: ‘ahamasmi, bhikkhave, brāhmaṇo yācayogo’ti, tena hi ‘rājāhamasmi selā’ti yaṁ vacanaṁ, taṁ micchā.
analyzed: aham asmi bhikkhave brāhmaṇaḥ tena hi rājā aham asmi yam tam micchā
translated: then the second statement must be false.

original: Yadi tathāgatena bhaṇitaṁ—
analyzed: yadi tathāgatena bhaṇita
translated: If the second statement was made by the Buddha,

original: ‘rājāhamasmi selā’ti, tena hi ‘ahamasmi, bhikkhave, brāhmaṇo yācayogo’ti tampi vacanaṁ micchā.
analyzed: rājā aham asmi tena hi aham asmi bhikkhave brāhmaṇaḥ tat pi vacanam micchā
translated: then the first statement must be false.

original: Khattiyo vā hi bhaveyya brāhmaṇo vā, natthi ekāya jātiyā dve vaṇṇā nāma, ayampi ubhato koṭiko pañho tavānuppatto, so tayā nibbāhitabbo”ti.
analyzed: khattiyaḥ vā hi bhaveyya brāhmaṇaḥ vā na atthi ekāya jātiyā dve vaṇṇā nāma ayam pi ubhatas koṭikaḥ pañhaḥ tava anuppatto saḥ tayā nibbāhitabbaḥ ti
translated: For a person can be either a noble or a brahmin, but there is no such thing as a person of two castes in a single birth. This double-pronged question has come up; it is for you to solve it.”

original: “Bhāsitampetaṁ, mahārāja, bhagavatā—
analyzed: mahā rāja bhagavatā
translated: “Great king, this was said by the Lord Buddha:

original: ‘ahamasmi, bhikkhave, brāhmaṇo yācayogo’ti, puna ca bhaṇitaṁ—
analyzed: aham asmi bhikkhave brāhmaṇaḥ puna ca bhaṇita
translated: ‘I am a brahmin, monks, a beggar.’ And again it is said:

original: ‘rājāhamasmi selā’ti, tattha kāraṇaṁ atthi, yena kāraṇena tathāgato brāhmaṇo ca rājā ca hotī”ti.
analyzed: rājā aham asmi tattha kāraṇaṃ atthi yena kāraṇena tathāgataḥ brāhmaṇaḥ ca rājā ca hoti iti
translated: ‘I am a king, a lord’, there is a reason for that, for which reason the Tathāgata is a brahmin and a king.”

original: “Kiṁ pana taṁ, bhante nāgasena, kāraṇaṁ, yena kāraṇena tathāgato brāhmaṇo ca rājā ca hoti”?
analyzed: kim pana bhante nāgasena kāraṇa yena kāraṇena tathāgataḥ brāhmaṇaḥ ca rājā ca
translated: “But what is that reason, reverend Sir, for which the Tathāgata is a brahmin and a king?”

original: “Sabbe, mahārāja, pāpakā akusalā dhammā tathāgatassa bāhitā pahīnā apagatā byapagatā ucchinnā khīṇā khayaṁ pattā nibbutā upasantā, tasmā tathāgato ‘brāhmaṇo’ti vuccati.
analyzed: sabbe mahā rāja pāpakāḥ akusalāḥ dhammāḥ tathāgatassa bāhitā pahīnāḥ apagatāḥ byapagatāḥ ucchinnā khīṇā khayam pattā nibbutāḥ upasantā tasmā tathāgataḥ brāhmaṇaḥ iti vuccati
translated: “All bad, unwholesome things, Great King, have been abandoned by the Tathāgata, given up, rejected, made non-existent, made to go no further, and because of that the Tathāgata is said to be a brahmin.

original: Brāhmaṇo nāma saṁsayamanekaṁsaṁ vimatipathaṁ vītivatto, bhagavāpi, mahārāja, saṁsayamanekaṁsaṁ vimatipathaṁ vītivatto, tena kāraṇena tathāgato ‘brāhmaṇo’ti vuccati.🔽Brāhmaṇo nāma sabbabhavagatiyoninissaṭo malarajagatavippamutto asahāyo, bhagavāpi,
analyzed: brāhmaṇaḥ nāma sa sayam anekasam vimati patham vītivattaḥ bhagavā api mahā rāja sa sayam anekasam vimati patham vītivattaḥ tena kāraṇena tathāgataḥ brāhmaṇaḥ iti vuccati  brāhmaṇaḥ nāma sabba bhava gati yoni nissaṭaḥ mala raja gata vippamuttaḥ asahāyaḥ bhagavā api
translated: A brahmin is one who has gone beyond doubt, the many parts (of ignorance), the path of uncertainty, and the Fortunate One, Great King, has gone beyond doubt, the many parts (of ignorance), the path of uncertainty, and because of that the Tathāgata is said to be a brahmin.

original: mahārāja, sabbabhavagatiyoninissaṭo malarajagatavippamutto asahāyo, tena kāraṇena
analyzed: mahā rāja sabba bhava gati yoni nissaṭaḥ mala raja gata vippamuttaḥ asahāyaḥ tena kāraṇena
translated: A brahmin is one who has escaped from all the destinations and forms of existence, who is free from the dust and dirt of the world, who is without a companion, and the Fortunate One, Great King,🔽has escaped from all the destinations and forms of existence, is free from the dust and dirt of the world, and is without a companion, and because of that the Tathāgata is said to be a brahmin.

original: tathāgato ‘brāhmaṇo’ti vuccati.
analyzed: tathāgataḥ brāhmaṇa iti vuccati
translated: the Realised One is said to be a Brahmin.

original: Brāhmaṇo nāma aggaseṭṭhavarapavaradibbavihārabahulo, bhagavāpi, mahārāja, aggaseṭṭhavarapavaradibbavihārabahulo, tenāpi kāraṇena tathāgato ‘brāhmaṇo’ti vuccati.
analyzed: brāhmaṇaḥ nāma agga seṭṭha vara pavara dibba vihāra bahulaḥ bhagavā api mahā rāja agga seṭṭha vara pavara dibba vihāra bahulaḥ tena api kāraṇena tathāgataḥ brāhmaṇaḥ iti vuccati
translated: A Brahmin is one who has much of the foremost, best, excellent, divine living, the Fortunate One, great king, has much of the foremost, best, excellent, divine living, for this reason also the Realised One is said to be a Brahmin.

original: Brāhmaṇo nāma ajjhayanaajjhāpanadānappaṭiggahaṇadamasaṁyamaniyamapubbamanusiṭṭhipaveṇivaṁsadharaṇo,
analyzed: brāhmaṇaḥ nāma ajjhayana ajjhāpana dāna ppaṭiggahaṇa dama sa yama niyama pubba manu siṭṭhi paveṇi vasa dharaṇaḥ
translated: A Brahmin is one who bears the lineage of the ancient instructions of the giving, receiving, taming, restraint, control, and the ancient training rules,

original: bhagavāpi, mahārāja, ajjhayanaajjhāpanadānappaṭiggahaṇadamasaṁyamaniyamapubbajināciṇṇaanusiṭṭhipaveṇivaṁsadharaṇo,
analyzed: bhagavā api mahā rāja ajjhayana ajjhāpana dāna ppaṭiggahaṇa dama sa yama niyama pubba jina āciṇṇa anusiṭṭhi paveṇi vasa dharaṇaḥ
translated: the Fortunate One, great king, bears the lineage of the ancient instructions of the giving, receiving, taming, restraint, control, and the ancient training rules,

original: tenāpi kāraṇena tathāgato ‘brāhmaṇo’ti vuccati.
analyzed: tena api kāraṇena tathāgataḥ brāhmaṇa iti vuccati
translated: for this reason also the Realised One is said to be a Brahmin.

original: Brāhmaṇo nāma brahāsukhavihārajjhānajhāyī;
analyzed: brāhmaṇaḥ nāma
translated: A Brahmin is one who meditates in the meditation of the divine living of the Great One,

original: bhagavāpi, mahārāja, brahāsukhavihārajjhānajhāyī, tenāpi kāraṇena tathāgato ‘brāhmaṇo’ti vuccati.
analyzed: bhagavā api mahā rāja tena api kāraṇena tathāgataḥ brāhmaṇa iti vuccati
translated: the Fortunate One, great king, meditates in the meditation of the divine living of the Great One, for this reason also the Realised One is said to be a Brahmin.

original: Brāhmaṇo nāma sabbabhavābhavagatīsu abhijātivattitamanucaritaṁ jānāti, bhagavāpi,
analyzed: brāhmaṇaḥ nāma sabba bhava abhava gatīsu abhijāti vattitam anucaritam jānāti bhagavā api
translated: A Brahmin is one who knows the conduct, the practice, and the performance in all existences, in all states of existence, and in all destinations, the Fortunate One, great king,

original: mahārāja, sabbabhavābhavagatīsu abhijātivattitamanucaritaṁ jānāti, tenāpi kāraṇena
analyzed: mahā rāja sabba bhava abhava gatīsu abhijāti vattitam anucaritam jānāti tena api kāraṇena
translated: He knows the births, the destinies, the courses of conduct of all beings in all states of existence, and for this reason

original: tathāgato ‘brāhmaṇo’ti vuccati.
analyzed: tathāgataḥ brāhmaṇa iti vuccati
translated: the Tathāgata is called a brāhmaṇa.

original: Brāhmaṇoti, mahārāja, bhagavato netaṁ nāmaṁ mātarā kataṁ, na pitarā kataṁ, na bhātarā
analyzed: brāhmaṇa uti mahā rāja bhagavataḥ na itam nāmam mātarā kata na pitarā kata na bhātarā
translated: “Brāhmaṇa,” your majesty, is not a name given to the Blessed One by his mother, his father, his relatives,

original: kataṁ, na bhaginiyā kataṁ, na mittāmaccehi kataṁ, na ñātisālohitehi kataṁ, na samaṇabrāhmaṇehi
analyzed: kata na bhaginiyā kata na mittāmaccehi kata na ñāti sālohitehi kata na samaṇa brāhmaṇehi
translated: his friends, or by his kinsmen, nor is it a name given by the ascetics and brāhmaṇas,

original: kataṁ, na devatāhi kataṁ, vimokkhantikametaṁ buddhānaṁ bhagavantānaṁ nāmaṁ bodhiyāyeva
analyzed: kata na devatāhi kata vimokkha antikam etam buddhānam bhagavantānam nāmam bodhiyāya iva
translated: nor is it a name given by the gods. It is a name that is derived from his emancipation. It is a name that is given to the Buddhas, the Blessed Ones,

original: mūle mārasenaṁ vidhamitvā atītānāgatapaccuppanne pāpake akusale dhamme bāhetvā saha
analyzed: mūle mārasenam vidhamitvā atīta anāgata paccuppanne pāpake akusale dhamme bāhetvā saha
translated: at the foot of the Bodhi tree, after he has crushed Māra’s army and has expelled all evil and unwholesome states, past, future, and present,

original: sabbaññutañāṇassa paṭilābhā paṭiladdhapātubhūtasamuppannamatte sacchikā paññatti
analyzed: sabbaññuta ñāṇassa paṭilābhā paṭiladdha pātubhūta samuppanna matte sacchikā paññatti
translated: and has attained the knowledge of omniscience. It is a name that is given to him by the realization of the knowledge that has been attained, that has been made manifest, that has arisen,🔽that is present, and that is to be realized. It is a name that is given to him by the realization of the knowledge that has been attained, that has been made manifest, that has arisen,

original: yadidaṁ brāhmaṇoti, tena kāraṇena tathāgato vuccati ‘brāhmaṇo’”ti.
analyzed: yat idam brāhmaṇa uti tena kāraṇena tathāgataḥ vuccati brāhmaṇa uti
translated: that is present, and that is to be realized. For this reason the Tathāgata is called a brāhmaṇa.”

original: “Kena pana, bhante nāgasena, kāraṇena tathāgato vuccati ‘rājā’”ti?
analyzed: kena pana bhante nāgasena kāraṇena tathāgataḥ vuccati rājā ati
translated: “But, revered sir, for what reason is the Tathāgata called a king?”

original: “Rājā nāma, mahārāja, yo koci rajjaṁ kāreti lokamanusāsati, bhagavāpi, mahārāja,🔽dasasahassiyā lokadhātuyā dhammena rajjaṁ kāreti, sadevakaṁ lokaṁ samārakaṁ sabrahmakaṁ
analyzed: rājā nāma mahā rāja yaḥ rajjam kāreti lokam anusāsati bhagavā api mahā rāja  dasasahassiyā lokadhātuyā dhammena rajjam kāreti sa devakam lokam sa mārakam sa brahmaka
translated: “A king, sire, is one who rules a kingdom and instructs the people. The Lord, sire,

original: sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiṁ pajaṁ sadevamanussaṁ anusāsati, tenāpi kāraṇena tathāgato vuccati ‘rājā’ti.
analyzed: sa samaṇa brāhmaṇim pajam sa deva manussam anusāsati tena api kāraṇena tathāgataḥ vuccati rājā ati
translated: rules by Dhamma a world with its gods, its Māras and its Brahmās, this generation with its recluses and brahmans, with its princes and its people, and he instructs it. For this reason, too, the Tathāgata is called ‘king.’

original: Rājā nāma, mahārāja, sabbajanamanusse abhibhavitvā nandayanto ñātisaṅghaṁ, socayanto🔽amittasaṅghaṁ, mahatimahāyasasiriharaṁ thirasāradaṇḍaṁ anūnasatasalākālaṅkataṁ ussāpeti🔽paṇḍaravimalasetacchattaṁ, bhagavāpi, mahārāja, socayanto mārasenaṁ micchāpaṭipannaṁ,
analyzed: rājā nāma mahā rāja sabba jana manusse abhibhavitvā nandayantaḥ ñāti saṅgha socayantaḥ  amitta saṅgha mahati mahāyasa siri haram thira sāra daṇḍam anūna sata salākā alaṅkatam ussāpa iti  bhagavā api mahā rāja socayantaḥ mārasenam micchā paṭipanna
translated: A king, sire, having overcome all men and women, delights his kinsmen and grieves🔽his enemies. He raises aloft a great and mighty parasol, which is a symbol of his firm and steadfast power, and which is marked with a thousand spokes.

original: nandayanto devamanusse sammāpaṭipanne dasasahassiyā lokadhātuyā mahatimahāyasasiriharaṁ
analyzed: nandayantaḥ deva manusse sammā paṭipanne dasa sahassiyā lokadhātuyā mahati mahā yasa siri hara
translated: The Lord, sire, having grieved Māra’s army which is in error, and having delighted gods and men who are in the right, raises aloft in the world with its gods, its Māras and its Brahmās, in this generation with its recluses and brahmans, with its princes and its people, a great and mighty parasol, which is a symbol of his firm and steadfast Dhamma,🔽and which is marked with the three knowledges.

original: khantithirasāradaṇḍaṁ ñāṇavarasatasalākālaṅkataṁ ussāpeti aggavaravimuttipaṇḍaravimalasetacchattaṁ,
analyzed: khanti thira sāra daṇḍam ussāpa iti agga vara vimutti paṇḍara vimala seta chatta
translated: raises the white parasol of the best, excellent, and pure freedom,

original: tenāpi kāraṇena tathāgato vuccati ‘rājā’ti.
analyzed: tena api kāraṇena tathāgataḥ vuccati rājā ati
translated: for this reason too the Realised One is said to be a ‘King’.

original: Rājā nāma upagatasampattajanānaṁ bahūnamabhivandanīyo bhavati, bhagavāpi, mahārāja, upagatasampattadevamanussānaṁ bahūnamabhivandanīyo, tenāpi kāraṇena tathāgato vuccati ‘rājā’ti.
analyzed: rājā nāma upagata sampatta janānam bahūnam abhivandanīyaḥ bhavati bhagavā api mahā rāja upagata sampatta deva manussānam bahūnam abhivandanīyaḥ tena api kāraṇena tathāgataḥ vuccati rājā ati
translated: A King is one who is worshipped by many people who have come and assembled, the Fortunate One, Great King, is worshipped by many gods and men who have come and assembled, for this reason too the Realised One is said to be a ‘King’.

original: Rājā nāma yassa kassaci ārādhakassa pasīditvā varitaṁ varaṁ datvā kāmena tappayati,
analyzed: rājā nāma yassa kassaci ārādhakassa pasīditvā varitam varam da tvā kāmena tappayati
translated: A King, after pleasing whoever has pleased him, gives a boon, and satisfies him with whatever he desires,

original: bhagavāpi, mahārāja, yassa kassaci kāyena vācāya manasā ārādhakassa pasīditvā varitaṁ🔽varamanuttaraṁ sabbadukkhaparimuttiṁ datvā asesakāmavarena ca tappayati, tenāpi kāraṇena
analyzed: bhagavān api mahā rāja yassa kassaci kāyena vācāya manasā ārādhakassa pasīditvā  varam anuttaram sabba dukkha parimuttim da tvā asesa kāma varena ca tappayati tena api kāraṇena
translated: the Fortunate One, Great King, after pleasing whoever has pleased him with body, speech, or mind, gives the boon

original: tathāgato vuccati ‘rājā’ti.
analyzed: tathāgataḥ vuccati rājā ati
translated: of the unsurpassed freedom from all suffering, and satisfies him with the boon of all that he desires, for this reason too the Realised One is said to be a ‘King’.

original: Rājā nāma āṇaṁ vītikkamantaṁ vigarahati jhāpeti dhaṁseti, bhagavatopi, mahārāja,
analyzed: rājā nāma āṇam vītikkamantam vigarahati jhāpeti dhaseti bhagavataḥ api mahā rāja
translated: A King punishes, burns, and destroys whoever transgresses his command, the Fortunate One, Great King,

original: sāsanavare āṇaṁ atikkamanto alajjī maṅkubhāvena oññāto hīḷito garahito bhavitvā vajjati
analyzed: sāsana vare āṇam atikkamantaḥ alajjī maṅku bhāvena oññātaḥ hīḷitaḥ gara hitaḥ bhavitvā vajjati
translated: he is despised, scorned, and blamed for his lack of shame and his timidity in transgressing the command in the excellent Dispensation.

original: jinasāsanavaramhā, tenāpi kāraṇena tathāgato vuccati ‘rājā’ti.🔽Rājā nāma pubbakānaṁ dhammikānaṁ rājūnaṁ paveṇimanusiṭṭhiyā dhammādhammamanudīpayitvā🔽dhammena rajjaṁ kārayamāno pihayito piyo patthito bhavati janamanussānaṁ, ciraṁ rājakulavaṁsaṁ
analyzed: tena api kāraṇena tathāgataḥ vuccati rājā ati  rājā nāma pubbakānam dhammikānam rājūnam paveṇim anusiṭṭhiyā dhamma adhammam anudīpayitvā  dhammena rajjam kārayamānaḥ pihayitaḥ piyaḥ patthitaḥ bhavati jana manussāna ciram rāja kula vasa
translated: He is expelled from the excellent Dispensation of the Victor. For this reason too the Realised One is called ‘King’.🔽A king, having pointed out what is right and wrong by the advice of his ancestors, the righteous kings,🔽and having ruled righteously, is desired, dear, and longed for by the people, and he establishes the royal lineage for a long time

original: ṭhapayati dhammaguṇabalena, bhagavāpi, mahārāja, pubbakānaṁ sayambhūnaṁ paveṇimanusiṭṭhiyā
analyzed: ṭhapayati dhamma guṇa balena bhagavā api mahā rāja pubbakānam sayambhūnam paveṇim anusiṭṭhiyā
translated: through the power of his good qualities and Dhamma. The Fortunate One, Great King, having pointed out what is right and wrong by the advice of his ancestors, the Self-Arisen Ones,

original: dhammādhammamanudīpayitvā dhammena lokamanusāsamāno pihayito piyo patthito devamanussānaṁ
analyzed: dhamma adhammam anudīpayitvā dhammena lokam anusāsamānaḥ pihayitaḥ piyaḥ patthitaḥ deva manussāna
translated: and having instructed the world righteously, is desired, dear, and longed for by gods and men,

original: ciraṁ sāsanaṁ pavatteti dhammaguṇabalena, tenāpi kāraṇena tathāgato vuccati ‘rājā’ti.
analyzed: ciram sāsanam pavatteti dhamma guṇa balena tena api kāraṇena tathāgataḥ vuccati rājā ati
translated: and he establishes the Dispensation for a long time through the power of his good qualities and Dhamma. For this reason too the Realised One is called ‘King’.

original: Evamanekavidhaṁ, mahārāja, kāraṇaṁ, yena kāraṇena tathāgato brāhmaṇopi bhaveyya rājāpi
analyzed: evam anekavidha mahā rāja kāraṇa yena kāraṇena tathāgataḥ brāhmaṇaḥ api rājā api
translated: In this way, Great King, there are many reasons why the Realised One would be a Brahmin and a King

original: bhaveyya, sunipuṇo bhikkhu kappampi no naṁ sampādeyya, kiṁ atibahuṁ bhaṇitena, saṅkhittaṁ
analyzed: bhaveyya su nipuṇaḥ bhikkhu kappam pi no nam sampādeyya kim ati bahum bhaṇitena saṅkhitta
translated: a very clever monk would not be able to complete it in a Kappa, what to say of a long time, in brief,

original: sampaṭicchitabban”ti.
analyzed: sampaṭicchitabbanti
translated: even a very clever monk would not be able to complete it in a lifetime. What is the use of talking a lot? It should be accepted in brief.”

original: “Sādhu, bhante nāgasena, evametaṁ tathā sampaṭicchāmī”ti.
analyzed: sādhu bhante nāgasena evam etam tathā sampaṭicchāmi iti
translated: “Good, revered Nāgasena, so it is, therefore do I accept it.”

original: Brāhmaṇarājavādapañho aṭṭhamo.
analyzed: brāhmaṇa rāja vāda pañhaḥ aṭṭhamo
translated: The Discussion with the Brahmins and the King, the Eighth.
